34AC4B816B11425287B6EEBEB2A20835.description: analyze and interpret data on natural hazards (earthquakes and volcanoes) to forecast future catastrophic events and influence the development of technologies to mitigate their effects. (MS-ESS3-2)

B324B53216134664BA4807480E7F98F8.description: develop a model to describe the cycling of Earth’s materials and the flow of energy that drives this process. (MS-ESS2-1)

357892AECD264800A47D776367F82447.description: construct an explanation based on evidence for how geoscience processes have changed Earth’s surface at varying time and spatial scales. (MS-ESS2-2)

6890E3A3613D4090BF0E36DD776AF0F8.description: construct a scientific explanation based on evidence from rock strata for how the geological time scale is used to organize Earth’s 4.6 billion year old history. (MS-ESS1-4)

186160388B6D4B9E8854DC65D3833318.description: analyze and interpret data on the distribution of fossils and rocks, continental shapes, and seafloor structures to provide evidence of the past plate motions. (MS-ESS2-3)

4D0882ACCDC44BBA830CAFBDFF5A728E.description: compare and contrast continental drift theory to plate tectonics.

77AE88D85EAE484CB8C6024E147EEA25.description: Outcome: Students will analyze and interpret geoscience data to explain how the movement of tectonic plates impacts the surface of the Earth.

04B0C78E181B4A97935CD7039FF71B6F.description: develop a model that describes atoms.

917F14057C754B93B9566B69CB779E43.description: identify basic components of the periodic table and that atoms make up the elements.

C11FFB9E66EB490BBFFE9B962071C61B.description: analyze data from test to determine similarities and differences among several design solutions to identify the best characteristics of each that can be combined into a new solution to better meet the criteria for success. (MS-ETS1-3)

6BEF51A7E6C24618A4D75C29F50550F4.description: develop a model to generate data for iterative(repetitive) testing and modification of a proposed object, tool or process such that an optimal design can be achieved. (MS-ETS1-4)

2C6B867EC0314D2AB5A4A52BCD4592EA.description: design, construct, and test a device that minimizes or maximizes thermal energy. (MS-PS3-3)

7D0EEA192655423182541D729A131004.description: plan an investigation to determine the relationships among the energy transferred, the type of matter, the mass, and the change in the average kinetic energy of the particles as measured by the temperature of the sample. (MS-PS3-4)

59EFF375757747378156554DCC19D187.description: develop a model that predicts and describes changes in particle motion, temperature, and state of a pure substance when thermal energy is added or removed. (MS-PS1-4)

B1AD0DD2373648F08A8E595D2F3566B4.description: Outcome: Students will evaluate the structure and properties of matter.

F5D167D1FB174C32A37C840722C2A960.description: construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for how environmental and genetic factors influence the growth of organisms. (MS-LS1-5)

4A59697408A340EBA69026210D103DE3.description: use argument based on empirical evidence and scientific reasoning to support an explanation for how characteristic animal behaviors and specialized plant structures affects the probability of successful reproduction of animals and plants respectively. (MS-LS1-4)

F08DFE5B3C954404AD45C7EF2438C872.description: develop and use a model to describe why asexual reproduction results in offspring with identical genetic information and sexual reproduction results in offspring with genetic variation. (MS-LS3-2)

D4CD348307FB41A7BA5906C8251597C4.description: develop and use a model to describe why structural changes to genes (mutations) located on chromosomes may affect proteins and may result in harmful, beneficial, or neutral effects to the structure and function of the organism. (MS-LS3-1)

32120C54F59E499A800C1D8D6B94F5BA.description: show how chromosomes are paired and contain two alleles of many genes.

50AA731958114BA0ABFD1AD06B1049B3.description: Outcome: Students will develop models to describe how gene mutations and reproduction contribute to genetic variation.

C8A93E28E4A44D6E8A4168B05EC4FF5A.description: gather and synthesize information that sensory receptors respond to stimuli by sending messages to the brain for immediate behavior or storage as memories. (MS-LS1-8)

06C5F02A6C3B4A53B08EFC13758D4895.description: use argument supported by evidence for how the body is a system of interacting subsystems composed of groups of cells. (MS-LS1-3)

BB2A74E8F03C4EBC8B16D7486391234A.description: develop and use a model to describe the function of a cell as a whole and the ways parts of cells contribute to the function. (MS-LS1-2)

7E97ABC0133B44968040D9C9937BC53A.description: differentiate among the functions of various cell structures.

CB8EBA91721549918F3C95248038FA9D.description: distinguish the cell structures of plant and animals with emphasis on nucleus, chloroplasts, mitochondria, cell membrane, cell wall.

36BC77D13EEB43C499C6EA7B74099C70.description: conduct an investigation to provide evidence that living things are made up of cells, either one cell or many different numbers and types of cells (nerve cells, muscle cells). (MS-LS1-1)

4546386AD8C54732BBCDBB21CDCC2FAE.description: Outcome: Students will construct explanations for the interactions of cells structures, cells within systems, and how organisms gather and use information from the environment.
